title: Need an `isEmpty` taking Object.getOwnPropertySymbols() into account
body:
Hi! I'm looking for a simple solution to find out if a `sequelize` query object is empty or not.

Using `_.isEmpty` is no good for `sequelize` uses `Symbol` keys for criteria grouping.

I hereby suggest an update to the documentation.

I think it should mention explicitely the call to `Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty` and feature an example with an object with symbols as keys.

title: interactive CLI?
body:
I just saw in ramda that you can use it on the command line, but it will allow you to test it in the browser before continuing, with `--interactive` https://github.com/raine/ramda-cli#interactive-mode

Any plans for such a thing with lodash?

title: Path format
body:
I couldn't find any docs about string path format used in the methods like has/get/set.
If an object has fields with `[` `]` `.` `'` `"` characters in the name, how such fields should be properly written in the string path?

title: Installed package.json contains link to parking/malware
body:
The installed `package.json` (i.e. in `my_project/node_modules/lodash/package.json` contains author information of:
```
  "author": {
    "name": "John-David Dalton",
    "email": "john.david.dalton@gmail.com",
    "url": "http://allyoucanleet.com/"
  },
```

This `url` is currently serving a redirect to malware. Please fix the domain, or remove it from the installed metadata.

(I'm not sure where it comes from.. maybe npmjs.com metadata? It doesn't seem to be in the source tree.)

title: avoid extensionless imports
body: This means lodash will work out of the box for things like [deno](https://github.com/denoland/deno).

title: Merge objects in array with same properties-values
lodash/fp get and set functions
body:
Hi Lodash 👋 

I wanted to clarify why lodash/fp `get` function don't return the same ref for the object if the object didn't have any changes?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7091543/51430585-409ee180-1c26-11e9-8560-84d48b65ead9.png)

In Functional Programming, we can know that the object has changes based on just the reference comparison, but here the `get` is returning a new reference without any changes to the state which seems wrong in FP.

I think that the right thing is to break the ref when setting the state by using `lodash/fp#set` function and then we can know that the object has changed from the prevState by the ref comparison.

I also have an issue when using set as so:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7091543/51430613-b6a34880-1c26-11e9-89da-4a485299ece7.png)

Why I'm getting a String corrupted output?

Thanks in advance ❤️

title: Access to private methods/fields from mixed in function
body:
There are a lot of useful methods hidden in the `.internal`. 
Is there any way to use them? May be from the scope of mixed in function?

Especially I need `castPath` and `parent` private methods to implement my own version of `hasPath` which will consider empty slots in sparse arrays.
Right now I see no other way than implementing my own path parsing, while it's already exists in the lodash.

title: get unique array from an object containing array of array object
Filter using like or contains
_(array).remove(...).some(...) mutables the original array
body:
```
a = [1,2,3]
_(a).remove(i => i == 2)
console.log(a) // [1, 2, 3]

a = [1,2,3]; 
_(a).remove(i => i == 2).some(i => true); 
console.log(a) // [1, 3]
```

title: Fix _.isFunction for async generator functions
body:
async generator function have a string representation that `isFunction` did not check against.

While adding the test for this, I also noticed that all the tests for `isFunction` only tested if `Function('string of function to test')` is a function, not the actual function that was supposed to be tested.

title: Use existing functions for more readable statements
body:
Hi,
I think to use ```isUndefined()``` and ```isNull()``` is better for making this code more readable since not only the naming of the functions are very clear, also they have been with ```lodash``` from the very beginning.

But in this code, I'm confused if this line wanted to check ```null``` and ```undefined``` _OR_ just ```null```. 
```javascript
... (separator != null && !isRegExp(separator))
```

I assumed this code aimed to only ```null```, but if ```undefined``` also has to be considered, we can use ```isNil()``` instead.
What do you think?

title: Changed to arrow function
body:
MDN Link - [Array.isArray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/isArray)

As long as the function only wants to check if the type of param is either ```null``` or ```undefined``` or ```Array```, I think this arrow function will work well too

title: Potentially unexpected behavior in null or undefined path elements
body:
When using `get` and array property path syntax, if one of the elements of the property path is `null` or `undefined`, but the structure under evaluation has a `"null"` or `"undefined"` as key, it will reach the value of that key:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/296796/51111625-e2749780-17fc-11e9-8fd3-014a62bfbdd0.png)


It’s caused by [toKey](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/a7e0428889f7c26fba5c6e7127cbb36a99e0eb44/.internal/toKey.js#L17) not checking for falsiness, casting it to string (`${value}`) and therefore not bailing. My question is, is this intentional design, or is it an oversight?

title: Suggesting addition of new API, 'keyMany'.
body: Like 'keyBy', except instead of keying on a 'by-last' basis, keys to a collection where each element advertises as being in that key group. Iteratee takes an element and optional key, returns a string array of which keys it should be grouped into.

title: Use the exported functions
body:
Imported some functions that do the exactly the same things as the original codes.

* line 32 - It seems ```object``` must be an object or the error will be printed out. (According to the description of this function) For the better performance, check if ```object``` is an object at the very beginning of the codes.

* line 35 - The original code in ```while``` was below
```javascript
/* ... */
object = object[key]
```
Because of this part, ```object``` was not immutable, so ```cloneDeep``` was needed to create a 
new object for the immutability and the safety of the original variable.

* line 45, 53 - Replaced with the existing exported functions which do the same thing.

----

Further question
* Since ```isIndex()``` has ```!!length``` in its return statement, isn't ```!!length``` unnecessary in ```hasPathIn.js``` file's return statement? It seems redundant.

title: _.startcase converts special characters
body:
example:
```js
let name = 'jórgen henley-trottingham smythe'
_.startCase(name)
// return 'Jorgen Henley Trottingham Smythe'
```
I get that in the majority of cases one would want to deburr, but it would be nice to just add this to the definition:
```ts
_.startCase(string, boolean:deburr=true)
```

title: _.debounce().cancel() is not working with Vue.js properly
body:
# Outline
I wanted to use the `_.debounce()` on the Vue.js, and it works. Unless I called the `cancel()` of it.

# Version Info

## lodash Version
- v4.17.x

## Vue.js Version
- v2.5.x

# Example Codes
```
new Vue(
  ...
  methods: {
    debounced: _.debounce(function() {doSomething()}, 1000),
    foo() {
      this.debounced()
    },
    cancelDebounced() {
      this.debounced.cancel()
    }
  }
  ...
)
```

# Guessed Reason
- Inside of the `initMethods` function
- [Code line of Vue.js](https://github.com/vuejs/vue/blob/dev/dist/vue.js#L3655)

# Summary
I solved this issue by implementing feature with different way.
BUT, I think it is quite weird for me, that is reason why I created this issue.
I want to hear your(the lodash commiter, organaizer etc...) opinion.
Do you think it is an issue for lodash?

title: New function: _.onceUnlessThrows
_.words should not split 2d and 3d
sortBy: Only evaluate iteratees when needed
body:
Summary:
Resolves #4067. Performance-wise, this incurs some extra administrative
overhead on all invocations. In exchange, we can see order-of-magnitude
improvements in cases where there are expensive “fallback iteratees”
that are rarely hit (e.g., a `JSON.stringify`).

Running the `sortBy` benchmarks included in `perf/perf.js` gives the
following results on my laptop (Intel i5-4300U with Chrome 67 on Linux):

  - “`_.sortBy` with `callback`”:
      - before this patch: 59,249 ops/sec ±2.65% (56 runs sampled)
      - after this patch: 54,504 ops/sec ±2.91% (56 runs sampled)
      - (new / old) ratio: 0.92 ± 0.05 (0.87–0.97)

  - “`_.sortBy` with `property` name”:
      - before this patch: 98,956 ops/sec ±2.37% (58 runs sampled)
      - after this patch: 93,793 ops/sec ±1.46% (58 runs sampled)
      - (new / old) ratio: 0.94 ± 0.04 (0.91–0.98)

…and these on a workstation (Intel W-2135 with Chrome 71 on Linux):

  - “`_.sortBy` with `callback`”:
      - before this patch: 66,071 ops/sec ±2.39% (61 runs sampled)
      - after this patch: 58,707 ops/sec ±2.82% (58 runs sampled)
      - (new / old) ratio: 0.89 ± 0.05 (0.84–0.94)

  - “`_.sortBy` with `property` name”:
      - before this patch: 132,945 ops/sec ±2.71% (56 runs sampled)
      - after this patch: 129,162 ops/sec ±3.30% (61 runs sampled)
      - (new / old) ratio: 0.97 ± 0.06 (0.92–1.03)

(Best-of-3 timing used in each case.)

We can see that there is usually a statistically significant _decrease_
in the overall performance in these existing benchmarks.

This commit does not add a new benchmark to observe the best-case
behavior because the Underscore.js API does not support multiple
iteratees in `sortBy`, which would be needed for a fair comparison.

Test Plan:
The newly added test cases fail before this commit, but pass after it.
All existing tests pass (`npm run validate` passes).

wchargin-branch: sortBy-lazy

title: debounce not cancel old timer when start a new timer
body:
When enable `maxWait` in a tight loop, debounce will start a new timer without cancel old timer. thus,  `timerExpired` will invoked many times when thread idle.

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/a7e0428889f7c26fba5c6e7127cbb36a99e0eb44/debounce.js#L195-L199

title: cloneDeep works differently in Jest
questions about _.chunk in Array category
body:
I have two questions about `_.chunk`:

1. If the param `number` in `_.chunk` is not a number, it will be right using the npm lodash,  return `[]`.
bug it will throw an error using the GitHub lodash.
```
import chunk from './source/chunk.js';

var arr = [1, 2, 3, 4]
console.log(chunk(arr, 's'));
```
![使用github上的源码的报错信息](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9148095/50630350-79c72880-0f7b-11e9-84fb-cda62f1ef596.png)

2. If the param `number` in `_.chunk` is not an integer,  it will be treated as an integer (by parseInt) by using the npm lodash, but it will be inconsistent using the Github lodash.

```
import chunk from './source/chunk.js';

var arr = [1, 2, 3, 4]
console.log(chunk(arr, 1.5));
// 使用npm包时，会一直输出[[1], [2], [3], [4]]
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9148095/50630515-2a352c80-0f7c-11e9-914d-b73d45af59d4.png)

Is it a mistake or is it intentional?

title: Calling methods without parameters
body:
I see that almost all methods can be called without parameters.
For example:
```js
_.concat() // []
_.wrap() // ƒ $u(n){ /* [wrapped with _.partial] */ return n}
_.clone() // undefined
_.isSymbol() // false
_.trim() // ""
```
But this is not documented. (Maybe I just not found it)
Are you planning documenting this or I should avoid using this methods without parameters?

This is important for type checking. For example now I can't write this typescript code:
```ts
interface ISomeInterface { }

function doSmth(...args: ISomeInterface[]) {
    return doSmthAnother(_.assign(...args));
}
```
because by lodash documentation `assign` has one required parameter:
`_.assign(object, [sources])`

title: Partition with multiple predicates
body:
`_.partition` is insanely useful for dividing a set of data into several named subsets.

Quite often, it is needed to divide a set of objects into more than two subsets.
A simple example:
```
const issues = [ 
  { id: 1, state: 'open' },
  { id: 2, state: 'closed' },
  { id: 3, state: 'in-progress' },
  { id: 4, state: 'open' },
];
```
Assume you need all three sets of open, closed and in-progress issues separately.

Now you would write something like this:
```
const [ openIssues, notOpenIssues ] = _.partition(issues, { state: 'open' });
const [ closedIssues, notOpenNotClosedIssues ] = _.partition(notOpenIssues, { state: 'closed' });
const [ inProgressIssues, otherIssues ] = _.partition(notOpenNotClosedIssues, { state: 'in-progress' });
```
The other way would be to use multiple filters, that will go through the original array extra times which seems as extra work.

My proposition:
```
const [ openIssues, closedIssues, inProgressIssues, otherIssues ] =
  _.partition(issues, { state: 'open' }, { state: 'closed' }, { state: 'in-progress' });
```

What is expected, that `openIssues` will be all the issues that satisfy the first predicate, then `closedIssues` will be all the issues that satisfy the second predicate but do not satisfy the first one, etc.

title: Empty slots in array
Fix minor documentation typos
body: Replaced some @param- with @param

title: `_.mapFind`?
body:
Coming from a lazily-evaluated language, one of the bad habits that I have in JavaScript is code like the following:

```javascript
const foos = [ /*... some elements ...*/ ];
return _.find(_.map(foos, "isAwesome"));
```

Unfortunately, this maps _all_ the elements of the array, and then performs the `find` operation over the resulting array. It'd be really nice if there was a hybrid of `find` and `map` which performs the `find` on the mapped elements, and only maps those elements until it gets one that resolves to `true`.

I'm aware that I can implement this through a reduce, but that's technically true of anything within spitting distance of a list comprehension. The reason we have simpler utility methods is to make it clearer (and more performant) in our code, and I think this would be a useful addition.

If folks are generally interested and positively disposed towards this addition, I'd be happy to provide a proposed `_.mapFind` implementation (modeled after `find`, unless I'm told otherwise).

A problem about _.camelCase()
body:
Hi, I want to know the implement of _.camelCase(), I try a test case like this:
`_.camelCase('Foo\'s Bar');  // => 'foosBar'`
The result is normal.
But, when I try this:
`_.camelCase('Foo"s Bar') // => 'fooSBar'`
The letter 'S' is **upper case**, it's not correct. 'S' should be in **lower case** like the first test case.
So I see the code of _.camelCase(), `var rsApos = "['\u2019]"` is lack of **double quote**. It should be `"['\u2019\"]"`.

title: [request] filterOut and keep
body:
the docs for `_.filter` mention

> Note: Unlike _.remove, this method returns a new array.

yet `_.remove` is not the equivalent of `_.filter`, except for the mutability.

AFAICS there is no function that returns a new array without those where the predicate returns true.

The equivalent functions that I expect would be smth like
* `_.filter` vs `_.keep` (new, mutates, returns removed items)
* `_.filterOut` (new, doesn't mutate) vs `_.remove`

The functionality of say `_.remove` can be achieved with `_.filter`, no doubt. **But one cannot use the shorthand predicates**, thus this request.

title: [lodash/fp] `difference` returns unexpected result
"_.difference" get unexpected result
body:
4.17.11

```js
// right
_.difference([1,3,5], [2,3,5])
[1]
```

```js
// wrong
_.difference([1,3,5,5], [2,3,5,2]) // in this case, expect [1,5]
[1] // but get only [1]
```

```js
// right
_.difference(['a', 'b', 'c', 'f'], ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']) 
["f"]
```

```js
// wrong
_.difference(['a', 'b', 'c', 'c'], ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']) // expect ['c']
[]
```

```js
// wrong
_.difference(['a', 'b', 'c', 'c', 'e'], ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']) // expect ['c', 'e']
[]
```


it looks like if there has same value item after item, it get wrong result ?

is this a bug or by design ?

https://repl.it/@crapthings/lodash4106

title: isMatchWith doesn't call customizer when targetObject does not contain some property of sourceObject
body:
example: 
**calling the customizer**
isMatchWith({a:'b'}, {a: 'f'}, (t,c) => console.log(t,c))
**b f**
false

**not calling the customizer**
isMatchWith({a:'b'}, {a: 'f',b:'c'}, (t,c) => console.log(t,c))
**[nothing output here, not even the propeties that exist in the targetObject like 'a']**
false

**expected**
customizer will be invoke on every match
**actual**
customizer is not called if source object contain properties that are missed in the target object

title: FP docs for invokeArgs slightly misleading
body:
Here's what the wiki currently says: > Methods that expect an array as their last or only argument:
> `assignAll`, `assignAllWith`, `assignInAll`, `assignInAllWith`, `defaultsAll`, `defaultsDeepAll`, `invokeArgs`, `invokeArgsMap`, `mergeAll`, `mergeAllWith`, `partial`, `partialRight`, `without`, & `zipAll` The argument order for `invokeArgs` is `(path, [args], object)`. Therefore the array is the second argument, not the last. I've replaced the paragraph above with two paragraphs in the wiki: > Methods that expect an array as their last or only argument:
> `assignAll`, `assignAllWith`, `assignInAll`, `assignInAllWith`, `defaultsAll`, `defaultsDeepAll`, `invokeArgs`, `invokeArgsMap`, `mergeAll`, `mergeAllWith`, `partial`, `partialRight`, `without`, & `zipAll` > > Methods that expect an array as their second argument:
> `invokeArgs`, & `invokeArgsMap` Not sure if any of the other methods there also expect an array as their second argument. I'm filing this issue here only because it seems like the wiki edit is unlikely to be noticed by anyone, and perhaps I've misunderstood something and the docs were actually correct.

title: Implement tests for master (v5) branch
body:

Let me know if/how i should implement

title: Replace MapCache by Map in memoize (#4094)
body:
Replaces MapCache by Map in memoize as stated in #4094

For the record i patched locally v4 and all tests passes

title: Use Map instead of MapCache in memoize
body:
By replacing MapCache by Map a considered amount of code (implementations of MapCache, Hash and ListCache) can be saved for those using only memoize

Even if MapCache is [still faster](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3117) than Map (may not be true anymore due to [recent](https://v8.dev/blog/hash-code) browser optimizations) probably is not relevant is real world usage. So IMO the trade off is worth.

Alternatively MapCache can be exposed to those that need this specific kind of optimization

The roadmap is not clear about support for browsers

_.upperFirst('LODASH') return 'LODASH'
body:
Hello, I'm front-end developer in South Korea.
I have some question in `._upperFirst` method

i have seen comment on method.
 @example
 _.upperFirst('fred');  => 'Fred'
 _.upperFirst('FRED'); => 'FRED'

 1. _.upperFirst('lodash') => 'Lodash'
 2. _.upperFirst('loDASH') => 'LoDASH'
 3. _.upperFirst('LODASH') => 'LODASH'

i expect example of 1,2,3 result => 'Lodash' 

If my expectation is correct can i fix `._upperFirst` ?

thank you,

title: fix: limit the precision when the precision is negative
body:
Signed-off-by: asilinwei <1021069119@qq.com>
There is a problem about _.floor():
`_.floor(12, Infinity)  // => 12`
But, when the precision is -Infinity:
`_.floor(12, -Infinity) // => NaN`
It is not very suitable because it is only limited the precision when the precision is positive.
It also should be limited the precision when the precision is negative.

title: _.floor() should be limited the precision when the precision is negative.
body:
Hi,  there is a problem about _.floor():
`_.floor(12, Infinity);  // => 12`
But, when the precision is negative:
`_.floor(12, -Infinity); // => NaN`
I saw the source code:
`precision = precision == null ? 0 : nativeMin(toInteger(precision), 292);`
is not very suitable because it is only limited the precision when the precision is positive, so I suggest this:
`precision = precision == null ? 0 : (precision = toInteger(precision) >= 0 ? nativeMin(precision, 292) : nativeMax(precision, -292));`

title: Remove unnecessary null check in arrayEach
body: `arrayEach` is called in three places: `baseClone`, `forEach` and `transform`. In each one, the call is preceded by a check that ensures the passed array is not null

title: Should support for PhantomJS be dropped in v5?

title: Call clearTimeout on debounce.flush (#4074)
body: Fixes #4074 but unlike proposed in the issue, calls clearTimeout outside of trailingEdge to avoid extra conditional check and unnecessary clearTimeout call, i.e., when timer is expired

title: [master] Call upperFirst directly, instead of capitalize, in camelCase (#4075)
body: Same as #4076 , but for master branch

title: Call upperFirst directly, instead of capitalize, in camelCase
body: This avoids double call to lowerCase. Fixes #4075

title: camelCase calls toLowerCase twice
body:
The camelCase function code is calling toLowerCase on each word:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/136d5253e724838ca701fb54db09f18b618c127e/camelCase.js#L23-L28

The capitalize function also calls toLowerCase though, so this is being performed twice on each word (except the first):
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/136d5253e724838ca701fb54db09f18b618c127e/capitalize.js#L16


Since string manipulations can be pretty costly, I think this is worth fixing. 

This is my first contribution to this project, so I apologize if I've missed anything.

body:
```
 * @returns {number} Returns the index at which `value` should be inserted

 * // => 1
```

NaN is returned if the first argument to sortedIndex is a non-array value. Don't you think you need to modify the annotation or exception to the return value?

- sortedIndexBy.js
- sortedLastIndex.js
- sortedLastIndexBy.js
@returns {number}

title: `sortBy` evaluates all iteratees even on non-ties
body:
Upon evaluating

    lodash.sortBy([2, 1], (x) => x, (x) => void console.log(x))

I was a bit surprised to see that two log statements are in fact printed
to the console, even though there are no ties on the first iteratee and
so the second iteratee need never be evaluated.

Upon looking at the implementation, it becomes clearer why this is the
case: you precompute all the `criteria` for each element so that they
only have to be computed once. But this makes use cases in which there
is a potentially expensive “fallback iteratee”, like

    sortBy(
        objects,
        (x) => x.id,  // almost all objects have distinct IDs
        (x) => JSON.stringify(x)  // expensive, but should happen only rarely!
    );

much more costly.

(All this holds the same for `orderBy`, of course.)

One could imagine an implementation that computes each criterion lazily,
only as it is needed to break a tie. From reading the docs, this would
appear to be a backward-compatible change; you don’t currently specify
under which circumstances the iteratees are invoked (which is good!).

Would you be interested in making or accepting such a change?

title: Would it be possible to replace `Function("return this")`
body:
Firefox DevTools runs Lodash in a privileged environment ([system principal]), where we would like to limit the use of `eval` for security reasons [1473549]. 

One example of this is `Function("return this")`, which appears in [root.js] [1496680] and is pulled into [redux.js] and [react-redux.js].

Would it be possible to limit this usage or in some other way replace it? 

```js
/** Used as a reference to the global object. */
const root = freeGlobal || freeSelf || Function('return this')()
```



[1473549]: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1473549
[1496680]: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1496680
[system principal]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Tech/XPCOM/Language_Bindings/Components.utils.Sandbox

[root.js]: https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4ea8c2ec249be046a0f4ae32539d652194caf74f/.internal/root.js#L7

[react-redux.js]: https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/b0b856065d5b7ad2996f707e6e797d0d72afd803/devtools/client/shared/vendor/react-redux.js#1536
[redux.js]: https://dxr.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/rev/b0b856065d5b7ad2996f707e6e797d0d72afd803/devtools/client/shared/vendor/redux.js#18
